Award.AwardTitle: SBIR Phase I: Actively Shielded Superconducting Generators for Large Wind Turbines
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is reduced levelized cost of electricity (LCOE) of offshore wind from current levels that are about twice that of onshore wind. Given the proximity of offshore wind resources to load centers along the coast, it is an attractive renewable energy source for the nation, but high costs are an impediment to widespread adoption. One way to address this is with larger turbines that can lead to lower ?balance of plant? costs, which can be as high as 65% of the total project costs of offshore wind. However, turbine rating is currently limited due to the large size and weight of the generator and the rotor, as well as infrastructure obstacles like manufacturing, transport, and assembly. The lightweight superconducting (SC) generators being developed within this project, coupled with advanced rotors already being developed by the OEM?s, could open the door to significantly larger turbine ratings and lower costs. The underlying high specific power machine technology can also help transform a number of other weight-sensitive electrical systems like hybrid electric airplanes and ship propulsion.

This Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project seeks to disrupt the traditional risk versus benefit trade of the low Technology Readiness Level (TRL) SC technology by significantly increasing the benefits with a novel ?active magnetic shielding? concept. This design concept enables a very high operating magnetic field within the machine while eliminating the need for a yoke made of ferromagnetic steel to contain the field. The higher internal fields increase the electromagnetic torque significantly over other solutions, leading to very high power density. Additionally, the elimination of heavy iron from the magnetic circuit leads to further reduction in weight. The proposed generator design can be about half the size of currently available wind direct-drives. Efficiency is also expected to improve with the elimination of about a third of copper coils while maintaining the same current density. Available cryogenic cooling technology from the commercially successful magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) industry will be adapted and utilized in the machine to reduce many of the cryogenics related risks while maintaining high specific power.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Through the Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project, a direct-drive wind generator design based on a new superconducting machine concept has been detailed using high fidelity electromagnetic and thermal modeling, and optimized with a genetic algorithm based design tool. The selected design is expected to achieve 5X stronger magnetic field in the airgap while eliminating the ferromagnetic material which is employed in the magnetic circuits of traditional electric machines. This design also eliminates the need for a gearbox, which introduces maintenance requirements and can add significant amount of weight and losses. As a result, the design is able to achieve a specific torque of 320 Nm/kg (with cryocooling system included), which is 8X above the typical values for conventional generators. The reduction in weight and volume of the generator can have a significant impact on the cost trade-offs between turbine, foundation, installation, and power transmission offshore by making fewer, larger turbines more practical. While conventional direct-drive and geared generators work well for medium sized turbines, they do not scale well to larger ratings.  According to the Energy Information Administration, bigger and more efficient turbines can improve capacity factor significantly and lead to substantial reduction in the Levelized Cost of Energy (LCOE).

The efficiency of the selected generator design is predicted to be 98%, which is an improvement of 2-4% over the conventional generators. At a 12MW turbine rating, this efficiency gain points to 1.2 – 2.4 GWh gain in annual energy output per wind turbine (assuming a capacity factor of 54% that is obtained in a typical offshore windfarm site). This corresponds to a $500k - $1M gain in Net Present Value (NPV), based on $20,000/MW/% using a conservative discount rate. Benchmarking with an earlier study by the DOE indicates that an 18 - 20% decrease in LCOE can be obtained from the corresponding weight reduction and efficiency gain. This projected decrease in LCOE of wind energy makes wind energy more economically competitive with fossil-fuel alternatives in some locations.

Detailed computer simulations to validate the performance has mitigated technical risks associated with maintaining the superconducting coils at the required cryogenic temperatures with a conduction cooled design, leading to a robust design of cryogenic cooling system for the generator.  To work towards hardware prototyping and commercial manufacturing, the team has also investigated manufacturability of the form-wound high frequency coils using Litz wire. Several trials have led the team to believe that manufacturing and assembly of the coils with tight tolerances and good resin penetration to improve thermal performance are achievable.

Overall, this project has led to increased knowledge on the broad topic of high magnetic field, air-core magnetic circuits, and conduction cooled superconducting assemblies for power applications.

Modified by: Andy Yoon

While conventional direct-drive and geared generators work well for medium sized turbines, they do not scale well to larger ratings.
